      instructors, colleagues, editors, mentors, classmates, siblings, parents,

afterPoints: >-
  We can engage in feedback in a variety of situations and with a variety of
  people, such as instructors, fellow students, and other people we trust.
---
In our study, we learned that feedback helps writers improve, whether it comes from an instructor, a peer, or a trusted friend.

Author Anne Gere explains that [feedback means showing other people our writing and thinking about what we can learn from their comments](https://www.fulcrum.org/epubs/x059c8342?locale=en#/6/20[Gere-0010]!/4/2[pt01]/24/1:408). When we engage with others’ feedback, we become aware of how different audiences can understand our writing.

points.point: School-sponsored feedback is [“peer review required by an institutional authority figure.”](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.5)
points.title: What is school-sponsored feedback?

points.point:
Self-sponsored feedback: [Writers can get feedback outside of school as a self-sponsored activity.](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.6)

It’s important to reach out to peers as well as to instructors, or those who are more knowledgeable, for feedback. As discussed in Chapter 2,

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="%5BA%5D%20connection%20emerged%20between%20authenticity%20and%20authority%20%u2026" fullText="%5B%5C%5BA%5D%20connection%20emerged%20between%20authenticity%20and%20authority%20so%20that%20an%20authentic%20audience%20of%20peers%20held%20a%20non-hierarchical%20authority%2C%20one%20founded%20on%20collaboration%20rather%20than%20competition%2C%20transaction%2C%20or%20control.%20This%20view%20of%20writing%20echoes%20what%20expert%20writers%20hope%20for%20when%20they%20imagine%20receiving%20feedback%20from%20their%20audience%20of%20peers%3A%20when%20an%20audience%20is%20not%20only%20a%20willing%20consumer%20of%20text%20but%20also%20an%20active%20responder%2C%20authority%20and%20audience%20are%20mutually%20constructed.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.11%29" />

Peers can offer feedback in ways that are truly collaborative. Writers who consistently show their work only to those who grade or evaluate their writing, [may want to find a peer](#what-is-school-sponsored-feedback).

Check out Charlotte’s perspective on self-sponsored feedback:

<ExpandableBlockquote previewText="Well%2C%20I%20do%20use%20peer%20editing%20as%20a%20huge%20thing%20%u2026" fullText="%5BWell%2C%20I%20do%20use%20peer%20editing%20as%20a%20huge%20thing%20I%20don%u2019t%20really%20enjoy%20using%20peer%20editing%20in%20class%20%u2026%20I%20like%20using%20people%20who%20I%20know%20I%20can%20trust%20as%20far%20as%20peer%20editing%2C%20which%20usually%20happens%20to%20be%20my%20mom%20a%20lot%2C%20or%20my%20friends%20that%20work%20at%20the%20Daily%20%5C%5Buniversity%20newspaper%5D%20or%20past%20teachers.%5D%28https%3A//hdl.handle.net/2027/fulcrum.10079890/poi.8%29" />

Peers in both school-sponsored and self-sponsored settings can provide useful feedback. Writing centers offer another way to get feedback. Writers can improve the quality of feedback by explaining where they need help.
